wiki_catalogs.name: System Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the InventoryCtrl_2 system. Explain its purpose as a full-stack inventory management solution built with ASP.NET Core 8.0 and Blazor WebAssembly. Describe the high-level architecture including frontend (Web.Client), backend API, shared libraries, and deployment infrastructure. Document the relationship between components such as how the Blazor UI interacts with the REST API via SignalR for real-time updates. Include conceptual overviews for beginners and technical details for experienced developers, highlighting key features like product management, transaction tracking, audit logging, and role-based access control. Provide practical examples of common workflows such as user login, inventory adjustment, and dashboard monitoring. Use terminology consistent with the codebase like 'AppDbContext', 'SignalRNotificationService', and 'WebApiServiceBase'. Illustrate with a system context diagram showing major components and their interactions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Docker Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the Docker configuration of InventoryCtrl_2. Detail the multi-container setup using docker-compose with services for API, Web.Client, PostgreSQL, and nginx. Explain environment-specific configurations for production, staging, test, and SSL-enabled deployments. Document service dependencies, network configuration, volume mappings, and port exposure strategies. Include health checks, restart policies, and resource constraints defined in each docker-compose file. Describe the Dockerfile build process for both the Inventory.API and Inventory.Web.Client projects, including layer optimization and artifact copying. Provide examples of customizing compose files for additional environments and integrating with CI/CD pipelines. Address common container startup issues, networking problems, and image build failures.

wiki_catalogs.name: Component Tree
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the frontend component tree of InventoryCtrl_2. Describe the hierarchical structure of Blazor components, starting from MainLayout and NavMenu as root layout components, down to functional dashboard widgets such as LowStockAlert, RecentActivity, and StatsWidget. Document the purpose, visual styling via CSS modules, and composition patterns used across components. Include examples of component parameters, event handling, and conditional rendering logic. Explain how component isolation and scoped styles are implemented using .razor.css files. Provide guidance on creating new components and integrating them into existing layouts. Address common issues such as CSS encapsulation conflicts and component lifecycle management.

wiki_catalogs.name: API Endpoints
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive API documentation for all RESTful endpoints in the InventoryCtrl_2 backend. Document each controller's HTTP methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE), URL patterns, request/response schemas using DTOs from Inventory.Shared, authentication requirements, and authorization roles. Include detailed examples for CategoryController and ProductController operations, showing request payloads and success/error responses. Explain pagination implementation in controllers like ProductController and CategoryController, including query parameters and response metadata. Document error handling patterns and status codes returned by controllers. Provide usage scenarios for each endpoint group, such as creating inventory transactions via TransactionController or managing users through UserController. Include Swagger/OpenAPI integration details and how to access interactive documentation.

wiki_catalogs.name: Entity Relationships
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the core entity relationships in InventoryCtrl_2. Detail the relationships between Product, User, InventoryTransaction, Warehouse, Location, Category, Manufacturer, and UnitOfMeasure. Explain one-to-many, many-to-one, and many-to-many associations (e.g., Product-ProductTag via ProductProductTags junction table). Document foreign key constraints, cascading delete behaviors, and referential integrity rules. Include examples from AppDbContext.cs OnModelCreating method showing relationship configurations. Illustrate how business rules are enforced through entity relationships (e.g., Transaction linked to Product and Location). Provide guidance on querying related data using Entity Framework Core navigation properties and best practices for avoiding performance pitfalls like N+1 queries.

wiki_catalogs.name: Unit Tests
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the unit testing strategy in InventoryCtrl_2. Focus on testing isolated business logic components such as services, models, and controllers using xUnit. Document the Arrange-Act-Assert pattern used across test cases, and provide examples from AuthServiceTests.cs and AuditServiceTests.cs. Explain how TestBase provides shared setup and mocking infrastructure. Cover validation of business rules in ProductTests.cs and CategoryTests.cs, and demonstrate edge case handling in RequestsControllerErrorHandlingTests.cs. Include guidance on writing new unit tests, leveraging FluentAssertions, and ensuring high code coverage. Address mocking practices using Moq for dependencies like DbContext and external services. Show how unit tests validate internal logic without HTTP or database integration.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the authentication system in InventoryCtrl_2. Document the JWT-based authentication flow including token generation, validation, and refresh mechanisms. Explain the implementation of AuthenticationMiddleware that intercepts API requests and validates Bearer tokens, with detailed coverage of the ValidateToken method and public endpoint exemptions. Detail the RefreshTokenService class responsible for generating, validating, and rotating refresh tokens, including token expiration policies and database persistence via UserManager. Cover secure token storage practices on the client side in Web.Client, and describe the login/logout workflows. Include configuration requirements in appsettings.json for JWT settings (Key, Issuer, Audience, ExpireMinutes). Provide examples of authentication headers, error responses for unauthorized access, and integration with ASP.NET Core Identity. Address security considerations such as token leakage prevention, brute force protection via rate limiting, and secure handling of refresh tokens.

wiki_catalogs.name: Product Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Product Management feature. Thoroughly explain the implementation details of CRUD operations in ProductController, including pagination, filtering, and soft delete mechanisms. Document the domain model relationships between Product, Category, Manufacturer, and UnitOfMeasure. Explain the use of computed CurrentQuantity property and integration with ProductOnHandView for real-time stock levels. Include concrete examples from the codebase such as SKU uniqueness validation, role-based IsActive field control, and audit logging via AuditService. Address common issues like handling concurrent updates and solutions for product search performance. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers.

wiki_catalogs.name: AppDbContext Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the AppDbContext in InventoryCtrl_2. Detail the DbContext inheritance from IdentityDbContext<User>, including the configuration of Entity Framework Core model building via OnModelCreating. Explain the setup of entity mappings for core domain models such as Product, Category, InventoryTransaction, and User. Document the configuration of relationships including one-to-many (User  AuditLog), many-to-many (Product  ProductTag), and optional references (Notification  Product). Include details on key constraints, index configurations (e.g., unique index on UnitOfMeasure.Symbol), and ReferentialAction settings (Restrict, Cascade, SetNull). Describe the use of HasDefaultValueSql for automatic timestamp population. Cover the registration of DbSets for all entities and keyless views. Provide guidance on extending the context with new entities, managing migrations, and ensuring schema consistency across environments.

wiki_catalogs.name: JWT Authentication Flow
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the JWT authentication flow in InventoryCtrl_2, focusing on the login process in AuthController. Explain how user credentials are validated using ASP.NET Identity, how claims are assembled (including role-based claims), and how access tokens are generated via RefreshTokenService. Document the structure of the JWT token including claims such as 'sub', 'jti', 'email', and role-based claims. Include configuration parameters like token expiration (Jwt:ExpireMinutes) and signing key. Provide examples of successful and failed login responses, including audit logging of login attempts. Detail error handling for invalid credentials and missing fields. Explain integration with rate limiting via 'AuthPolicy' and logging with Serilog.

wiki_catalogs.name: Product API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive API documentation for the ProductController endpoints in the InventoryCtrl_2 system. Document all HTTP methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE) for product management, including URL patterns like /api/products, /api/products/{id}, and /api/products/search. Detail request/response schemas using CreateProductDto, UpdateProductDto, and ProductDto from Inventory.Shared. Explain authentication requirements (JWT) and authorization roles (Admin, Manager). Document the stock adjustment endpoint at /api/products/{id}/stock/adjust with ProductStockAdjustmentDto. Include examples of creating a product with required fields (Name, SKU, CategoryId, ManufacturerId), updating product details, and searching products with query parameters. Explain pagination implementation with page and pageSize query parameters, and describe error responses for validation failures. Document the low-stock products endpoint and its filtering behavior based on MinStock thresholds.

wiki_catalogs.name: Audit Middleware
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the AuditMiddleware component. Thoroughly explain its implementation, including how it captures HTTP request and response details, measures execution time using Stopwatch, and enriches audit logs with metadata such as client IP address, user agent, and request ID. Document the logic for determining ActionType based on HTTP method (GET=Read, POST=Create, etc.) and extracting entity type from API route segments. Describe the mechanism for bypassing auditing on static assets and health endpoints via the ShouldSkipAuditing method. Explain how the middleware safely intercepts the response stream without corrupting it, using MemoryStream and proper stream restoration. Detail integration with AuditService via dependency injection to persist audit entries with success/failure status and severity levels. Include examples from the code showing structured logging patterns and error handling during audit logging. Address performance considerations such as memory usage during response buffering and best practices for excluding high-volume non-critical paths from auditing.

wiki_catalogs.name: Technology Stack
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the technology stack of InventoryCtrl_2. Detail the use of ASP.NET Core 8.0 for backend services, Blazor WebAssembly for frontend UI, Entity Framework Core for data access, PostgreSQL as the database backend, and SignalR for real-time communication. Explain the role of JWT for authentication, Serilog for structured logging, FluentValidation for input validation, and Radzen UI components for the frontend. Document version compatibility, framework-specific configurations in Program.cs, and integration patterns between technologies. Include practical examples from the codebase such as service registration in DI container, middleware pipeline setup, and client-side API consumption. Address performance considerations, scalability implications, and best practices for each technology. Provide guidance on extending or replacing components within the stack.

wiki_catalogs.name: nginx Setup
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the nginx reverse proxy setup in InventoryCtrl_2. Explain the role of nginx as a reverse proxy and static file server for the Blazor WebAssembly frontend and API gateway. Document the main nginx.conf configuration including worker processes, MIME types, and Gzip compression. Describe the staging and production-specific configurations for SSL termination, HTTP/HTTPS redirection, and location-based routing defined in nginx-staging.conf and nginx-staging-http.conf. Detail the upstream server definitions and proxy pass rules in conf.d/locations.conf that route requests to backend services. Include instructions for customizing location blocks for new API endpoints or static assets. Provide performance tuning recommendations, such as keepalive settings, buffer sizes, and caching strategies. Address common issues like 502 Bad Gateway errors, misrouted requests, and static file loading failures.

wiki_catalogs.name: State Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop comprehensive documentation for the state management system in InventoryCtrl_2's frontend. Explain how application state is managed through service-based dependency injection, including authentication state via CustomAuthenticationStateProvider, user session management, and real-time notification state. Detail the integration between Blazor's AuthenticationStateProvider and JWT token handling via TokenManagementService. Document how services like NotificationApiService and UserManagementService maintain and propagate state across components. Include examples of state synchronization between UI and backend, error handling during state updates, and strategies for managing loading, success, and error states. Provide best practices for avoiding memory leaks and ensuring reactive updates.

wiki_catalogs.name: ORM Models
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the Entity Framework Core models in InventoryCtrl_2. Detail the AppDbContext configuration including entity mappings, relationships, constraints, and database views. Explain the Product entity's relationship with Category, Manufacturer, and ProductTags, including the many-to-many configuration. Document the InventoryTransaction model with its transaction types (Income, Outcome, Install, Pending) and associations with Product and Location. Describe the User model inheritance from IdentityDbContext and its relationships with audit logs and notifications. Include information about keyless entities like ProductPendingView and their SQL view mappings. Document data validation rules, indexes for performance optimization, and the use of HasDefaultValueSql for timestamp fields. Provide guidance on extending the model with new entities and maintaining database schema consistency.

wiki_catalogs.name: Views and Indexes
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for database views and indexes in InventoryCtrl_2. Document the three key SQL views: vw_product_pending, vw_product_on_hand, and vw_product_installed, including their schema, purpose, and usage in dashboard and reporting features. Explain how these views are mapped in EF Core using keyless entities in AppDbContext.cs. Cover the critical performance indexes added via the AddCriticalPerformanceIndexes migration, including fields indexed, index types, and performance impact. Reference apply-indexes.sql for additional indexing strategies. Include examples of complex queries from reconcile-quantities.sql that leverage these views and indexes. Address query optimization techniques, index maintenance, and monitoring strategies for production environments.

wiki_catalogs.name: Integration Tests
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the integration testing layer of InventoryCtrl_2. Explain how integration tests validate end-to-end behavior across HTTP endpoints, database persistence, and authentication using TestServer and in-memory databases. Use AuthControllerIntegrationTests.cs and CategoryControllerIntegrationTests.cs as examples to demonstrate full request/response cycles. Detail the use of appsettings.Test.json for test-specific configuration. Describe the RequestCreationFlowTests.cs as a critical workflow test covering multi-step business processes. Document how TestBase initializes the application host and shares test fixtures. Provide examples of asserting side effects like database changes and audit logs. Include best practices for test isolation, transaction rollback, and performance considerations when running integration suites.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authorization
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the role-based authorization system in InventoryCtrl_2. Explain the implementation of Admin, Manager, and User roles using ASP.NET Core Identity and JWT claims. Document how roles are assigned to users during registration and management, and how they are embedded in JWT tokens via GenerateAccessTokenAsync. Describe the use of [Authorize(Roles = ...)] attributes on API controllers and actions to enforce access control. Provide examples from controllers like ProductController and UserController showing role-based permissions. Cover the integration with Policy-based authorization through custom requirements if implemented, and explain fallback behaviors for unauthorized requests. Include guidance on adding new roles, modifying role permissions, and testing authorization scenarios. Address common issues such as role claim missing in token, incorrect role assignment, and elevation of privilege vulnerabilities. Provide code examples demonstrating role checks in services and middleware.

wiki_catalogs.name: Inventory Transactions
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Inventory Transactions feature. Thoroughly explain the implementation details of transaction handling in TransactionController, including filtering by product, warehouse, type, and date range. Document the domain model relationships between InventoryTransaction, Product, Warehouse, User, and Location. Explain the transaction types (Income, Outcome, Install, Pending) and their business significance. Include concrete examples from the codebase such as transaction creation flow, quantity validation, and audit logging integration. Address common issues like handling negative quantities and solutions for transaction history tracking. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers.

wiki_catalogs.name: Product Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the Product entity in InventoryCtrl_2. Detail its properties including Id, SKU, Name, Description, CategoryId, ManufacturerId, ModelId, GroupId, UnitOfMeasureId, and audit fields (CreatedAt, CreatedBy). Explain the relationships: many-to-one with Category, Manufacturer, ProductModel, ProductGroup, and UnitOfMeasure; one-to-many with InventoryTransaction and ProductHistory; and many-to-many with ProductTag via the ProductProductTags join table. Document data validation rules such as required fields, string length limits, and uniqueness constraints (SKU). Include information about computed properties or shadow properties if present. Describe how the Product entity integrates with views like ProductOnHandView and ProductPendingView for inventory reporting. Provide examples of common queries involving Product and performance considerations such as indexing strategies on SKU and CategoryId.

wiki_catalogs.name: Token Refresh Mechanism
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the token refresh mechanism implemented in AuthController's Refresh endpoint and RefreshTokenService. Explain how a valid refresh token is validated against the user's stored token and expiration timestamp. Document the generation of a new access token and rolling refresh token (rotation) to enhance security. Describe the process of updating the user's refresh token in the database via SetRefreshTokenAsync. Include configuration settings such as Jwt:RefreshTokenExpireDays (default 7 days). Provide examples of successful refresh responses and error cases (invalid or expired refresh tokens). Address security considerations such as token revocation on logout and protection against replay attacks.

wiki_catalogs.name: Category API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed API documentation for the CategoryController endpoints. Document all CRUD operations including POST /api/Category for creating categories, GET /api/Category for retrieving paginated categories, GET /api/Category/root for root categories, and GET /api/Category/{parentId}/sub for subcategories. Include request/response schemas using CreateCategoryDto and UpdateCategoryDto from Inventory.Shared. Explain hierarchical category structure implementation and how parentId establishes parent-child relationships. Detail validation rules enforced by CreateCategoryDtoValidator and UpdateCategoryDtoValidator. Document authentication (JWT) and authorization requirements (Admin, Manager roles). Provide usage examples for creating nested categories and retrieving category trees. Explain error handling for cases like invalid parent IDs or circular references. Include details on pagination parameters and response metadata.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication Middleware
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the AuthenticationMiddleware component. Explain its role in enforcing JWT-based authentication for API endpoints while allowing anonymous access to Blazor UI routes and public APIs like login and health checks. Document the request flow: how it identifies API vs. non-API routes using StartsWithSegments, skips authentication for public endpoints defined in IsPublicEndpoint, and validates Bearer tokens using JwtSecurityTokenHandler and TokenValidationParameters. Describe the ValidateToken method's implementation, including issuer, audience, lifetime, and signing key validation with configurable clock skew. Explain how configuration values are injected from appsettings.json via IConfiguration. Detail the HandleUnauthorized method's behavior in returning standardized 401 responses with JSON error payloads. Include code examples showing token validation logic and exception handling. Address security considerations such as protection against expired tokens, proper error logging without exposing sensitive data, and defense against common JWT attacks. Provide guidance on extending the middleware for role-based or claim-based authorization.

wiki_catalogs.name: Directory Structure Breakdown
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the directory structure of InventoryCtrl_2. Explain the purpose and contents of each top-level directory: src/ (containing API, Shared, UI, Web.Assets, Web.Client), test/ (unit, integration, component tests), deploy/ (PowerShell deployment scripts and nginx configurations), scripts/ (SQL and utility scripts), and AgentTools/ (patching utilities). Detail the organization within src/ showing how Inventory.API contains controllers, services, and EF Core models while Inventory.Web.Client houses Blazor components and API clients. Document the role of shared libraries in enabling code reuse between frontend and backend. Include practical examples of navigating the codebase, locating specific features, and understanding component relationships through directory layout. Provide guidance on where to add new features or modify existing functionality based on the structure.

wiki_catalogs.name: SSL/TLS Implementation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for SSL/TLS implementation in InventoryCtrl_2. Detail the certificate generation process using PowerShell and Linux scripts (generate-ssl.ps1, generate-ssl-linux.sh) for development and staging environments. Explain the integration of SSL certificates with nginx configuration for HTTPS termination, including certificate and key file locations, SSL protocols, and cipher suites. Document the docker-compose.ssl.yml configuration that mounts certificates into the nginx container. Cover the automated deployment workflows using deploy-with-ssl.ps1 and deploy-with-ssl-fixed.ps1 scripts, including certificate validation and deployment diagnostics via diagnose-ssl.ps1. Reference troubleshooting guidance from SSL_TROUBLESHOOTING.md for common issues like certificate expiration, chain validation errors, and mixed content warnings. Provide best practices for managing certificates in production, including renewal processes and security considerations for private key storage.

wiki_catalogs.name: API Clients
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create in-depth documentation for the API client architecture in InventoryCtrl_2. Detail the implementation of WebApiServiceBase as a generic base class for entity-specific services, covering CRUD operations, pagination, and type safety. Explain the role of ResilientApiService in providing retry logic, API health checks, and fault tolerance with exponential backoff and jitter. Document how InterceptedHttpClient and JwtHttpInterceptor handle JWT token injection, request interception, and authentication header management. Describe the error handling pipeline through ApiErrorHandler and integration with logging. Provide code examples showing how to extend WebApiServiceBase for new entities and customize retry behavior. Address performance considerations and debugging techniques for API communication issues.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication Flow
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the JWT-based authentication system in InventoryCtrl_2. Explain the complete flow from user login via AuthController to token generation, including credential validation and claims assignment. Document the AuthenticationMiddleware's role in validating Bearer tokens for API endpoints, handling public vs. secured routes, and extracting user information. Describe the refresh token mechanism implemented in RefreshTokenService for maintaining user sessions. Include details about token expiration policies, secure storage considerations, and the VAPID configuration for web push notifications. Provide examples of successful and failed authentication scenarios, including error responses. Address security considerations such as token signing key management, protection against replay attacks, and secure transmission requirements. Document how role-based authorization is enforced after successful authentication.

wiki_catalogs.name: Migration Strategy
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the Entity Framework Core migration strategy in InventoryCtrl_2. Detail the migration history including InitialCreate, RemoveProductQuantityField, and AddCriticalPerformanceIndexes, explaining the purpose and impact of each. Document the workflow for creating, applying, and rolling back migrations in development and production environments. Explain the role of AppDbContextModelSnapshot.cs in migration consistency. Cover database initialization via DbInitializer.cs and seed data patterns. Include guidance on handling migration conflicts, scripting migrations for deployment, and zero-downtime strategies. Reference init-db.sql for initial schema setup and demonstrate how migrations evolve the database schema over time while preserving data integrity.

wiki_catalogs.name: Component Tests
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Blazor component testing strategy in InventoryCtrl_2. Focus on testing UI components in isolation using bUnit or similar frameworks, covering rendering behavior, event handling, and state changes. Use LowStockAlertTests.cs and StatsWidgetTests.cs to illustrate dashboard component validation. Explain how HomePageTests.cs verifies layout and navigation integration. Document testing patterns for user interactions in ProductCardTests.cs and form inputs in CategoryManagementWidgetTests.cs. Include validation of real-time updates via SignalR in ToastNotificationTests.cs. Show how TestBase provides consistent Blazor test context setup. Address accessibility checks, responsive behavior, and error state rendering in LoadingSpinnerTests.cs. Provide guidance on simulating authentication state and mocking API calls during component tests.

wiki_catalogs.name: Rate Limiting
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the rate limiting implementation in InventoryCtrl_2. Document the use of ASP.NET Core's RateLimiter middleware configured in Program.cs with token bucket and fixed window algorithms. Explain the global rate limiter that partitions limits by user role (Admin: 1000, Manager: 500, User: 100, Anonymous: 50 requests per minute). Detail the 'AuthPolicy' for login endpoints using fixed window limiting (5 attempts per 15 minutes) to prevent brute force attacks. Describe the 'ApiPolicy' for general API protection with role-based token bucket limits. Cover the rejection response format with 429 status code, JSON error payload, and retry-after guidance. Explain integration with nginx for additional layer 7 protection as defined in locations.conf. Provide configuration options for adjusting limits, handling queue overflow, and logging rate limit events. Include examples of rate-limited scenarios and client-side handling of 429 responses. Address performance implications and tuning recommendations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Real-time Notifications
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Real-time Notifications feature. Thoroughly explain the implementation details of SignalR-based real-time communication through NotificationHub, including connection management and message broadcasting. Document the domain model of Notification with its properties like Type, Duration, and IsDismissible. Explain the service layer implementation in NotificationService for triggering stock alerts and system notifications. Include concrete examples from the codebase such as TriggerStockLowNotificationAsync implementation and client-side subscription patterns. Address common issues like connection persistence and solutions for notification delivery guarantees. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers.

wiki_catalogs.name: Inventory Transaction Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the InventoryTransaction entity in InventoryCtrl_2. Detail its properties: Id, ProductId, LocationId, TransactionType (Income, Outcome, Install, Pending), Quantity, TransactionDate, ReferenceNumber, Notes, and audit fields. Explain the relationships: many-to-one with Product, Location, and User (via CreatedBy); and optional reference to Request. Document the TransactionType enum usage and business logic implications for each type (e.g., Pending reduces available stock). Include data validation rules such as positive quantity enforcement and required fields. Describe how transactions affect inventory views (ProductOnHandView, ProductInstalledView) and trigger audit logs. Provide examples of common transaction workflows and performance considerations like indexing on ProductId and TransactionDate for reporting queries.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication Middleware
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the custom AuthenticationMiddleware in InventoryCtrl_2. Explain its role in intercepting HTTP requests to API endpoints and validating Bearer JWT tokens. Detail the logic for bypassing authentication for non-API routes, public endpoints (e.g., /api/auth/login, /swagger), and static files. Describe the token validation process using JwtSecurityTokenHandler and TokenValidationParameters, including issuer, audience, lifetime, and signing key validation. Document the handling of unauthorized requests with a standardized 401 response. Include the configuration dependencies (Jwt:Key, Jwt:Issuer, Jwt:Audience) and logging practices using ILogger. Provide examples of middleware behavior for different request types and error scenarios.

wiki_catalogs.name: Transaction API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive API documentation for the TransactionController endpoints that manage inventory movements. Document endpoints for creating different transaction types (Income, Outcome, Install, Pending) via POST /api/transactions, retrieving transactions with GET /api/transactions, and retrieving product-specific transactions via GET /api/transactions/product/{productId}. Detail the TransactionDto schema including properties like ProductId, WarehouseId, Quantity, TransactionType, and Reference. Explain business rules for each transaction type and their impact on inventory levels. Document authentication requirements (JWT) and authorization roles (Admin, Manager, User). Include examples of creating an income transaction to restock inventory and an outcome transaction for fulfillment. Explain pagination implementation and filtering options. Describe error responses for invalid quantities, insufficient stock for outcome transactions, and invalid transaction types.

wiki_catalogs.name: Global Exception Middleware
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the GlobalExceptionMiddleware component. Explain its purpose as a centralized error handler that catches unhandled exceptions across the entire request pipeline. Document the implementation of InvokeAsync with try-catch wrapping the request delegate, ensuring all exceptions are intercepted before reaching the client. Describe how it enriches error logging with contextual data including request ID, HTTP method, path, query string, client IP (via X-Forwarded-For/X-Real-IP headers), and user agent. Explain the integration with IDebugLogsService to persist error details in debug logs when available, without failing the main response if logging fails. Detail the HandleExceptionAsync method's logic in mapping exception types to appropriate HTTP status codes and user-friendly error messages using GetErrorDetails (e.g., ArgumentException  400, UnauthorizedAccessException  401). Show how it constructs consistent JSON error responses with camelCase formatting using JsonSerializerOptions. Include examples from the code demonstrating structured error payloads with requestId, timestamp, and exception type. Address performance and reliability considerations such as avoiding infinite loops, preventing information leakage in production, and ensuring minimal overhead during normal operation.

wiki_catalogs.name: Frontend Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the frontend architecture of InventoryCtrl_2. Describe the Blazor WebAssembly implementation, component-based UI design, and integration with backend services through API clients. Explain the role of WebApiServiceBase, ResilientApiService, and InterceptedHttpClient in handling HTTP requests with JWT authentication and error handling. Document the state management approach using services like NotificationApiService and UserManagementService. Detail the routing structure, layout components (MainLayout, NavMenu), and theming system using CSS files in Web.Assets. Include system context diagrams showing component hierarchy and data flow. Address cross-cutting concerns like authentication state management via CustomAuthenticationStateProvider, logging through LoggingService, and validation with RequestValidator. Provide examples from actual components like Dashboard widgets and form handlers.

wiki_catalogs.name: Routing Structure
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Document the routing structure of the Blazor WebAssembly frontend in InventoryCtrl_2. Explain how routes are defined using @page directives in Razor components, with a focus on the Home page and future route extensions. Describe the integration between Blazor's Router component and the MainLayout for consistent navigation experience. Detail how navigation events are handled through NavMenu and routed to appropriate pages. Explain the relationship between frontend routes and backend API endpoints, particularly how ApiUrlService resolves base URLs. Cover best practices for route parameter handling, route guarding based on authentication state, and SEO considerations in a client-side routed application. Provide examples of adding new routes and organizing route hierarchies.

wiki_catalogs.name: Middleware Pipeline
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the ASP.NET Core middleware pipeline in InventoryCtrl_2. Explain the execution order of middleware components including AuthenticationMiddleware, AuditMiddleware, and GlobalExceptionMiddleware. Detail how AuditMiddleware captures request/response details, measures execution time, and logs audit entries through AuditService with enhanced context including IP address and user agent. Describe the AuthenticationMiddleware's logic for bypassing authentication on non-API routes and public endpoints while enforcing JWT validation on secured routes. Document GlobalExceptionMiddleware's error handling strategy, including structured logging, exception categorization, and standardized error responses. Explain how middleware components access services through dependency injection and the proper configuration in Program.cs. Include performance implications and best practices for middleware ordering. Provide guidance on extending the pipeline with custom middleware for cross-cutting concerns.

wiki_catalogs.name: CORS Policy
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing) configuration in InventoryCtrl_2. Document the two CORS policies defined in Program.cs: the default policy applied via AddCorsConfiguration extension and the 'SignalRPolicy' for WebSocket connections. Explain how the default policy reads allowed origins from the CORS_ALLOWED_ORIGINS environment variable, falling back to localhost URLs in development. Detail the SignalRPolicy requirements for AllowCredentials and how it enables SignalR hub connections from trusted origins. Cover the configuration of CORS middleware order (UseCors after routing, before authentication) and its interaction with SignalR. Describe the nginx reverse proxy configuration in locations.conf that may also enforce CORS at the infrastructure level. Provide guidance on securing CORS in production, avoiding wildcard origins, and preventing CSRF vulnerabilities. Include examples of preflight requests, common CORS errors, and troubleshooting steps for blocked cross-origin requests. Address the relationship between CORS and authentication headers.

wiki_catalogs.name: Audit Logging
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Audit Logging feature. Thoroughly explain the implementation details of audit trail generation in AuditService, including entity change tracking and JSON serialization of old/new values. Document the domain model of AuditLog with its comprehensive fields like EntityName, Action, Changes, and RequestId. Explain the integration with controllers for logging CREATE, UPDATE, and DELETE operations. Include concrete examples from the codebase such as LogEntityChangeAsync usage in ProductController and the GetActionTypeFromString helper method. Address common issues like performance impact and solutions for audit data retention. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers.

wiki_catalogs.name: User Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the User entity in InventoryCtrl_2. Explain its inheritance from IdentityUser<string> and extension with custom properties such as FirstName, LastName, PhoneNumber, and ProfilePictureUrl. Document the relationships: one-to-many with AuditLog, Notification, SignalRConnection, and NotificationPreference; and ownership of Requests. Include details on role-based authorization integration via ASP.NET Core Identity and claims. Describe how UserId is used as a foreign key across the system for audit and personalization. Cover data validation rules and constraints on extended properties. Provide guidance on user management operations, profile updates, and security considerations such as password policies and refresh token handling via RefreshTokenService.

wiki_catalogs.name: Refresh Token Service
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the RefreshTokenService class, which manages the lifecycle of refresh tokens in InventoryCtrl_2. Explain each method: GenerateRefreshToken (cryptographically secure token generation using RandomNumberGenerator), SetRefreshTokenAsync (database persistence with expiry), ValidateRefreshToken (comparison and expiration check), RevokeRefreshTokenAsync (nullification on logout), and CleanupExpiredTokensAsync (background cleanup task). Document the integration with ASP.NET Identity's UserManager<User> for user data access and updates. Include security considerations such as base64 encoding, secure storage, and protection against token leakage. Describe configuration parameters (Jwt:RefreshTokenExpireDays) and logging practices for auditability.

wiki_catalogs.name: User API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed API documentation for the UserController endpoints that handle user management. Document endpoints for user CRUD operations including GET /api/User for retrieving paginated users, POST /api/User for creating users, PUT /api/User/{id} for updating users, and DELETE /api/User/{id} for deactivating users. Detail the UserDto schema with properties like Username, Email, Role, and IsActive status. Explain role-based access control with Admin, Manager, and User roles. Document authentication requirements (JWT) and authorization (Admin role required for user management). Include examples of creating a new user with role assignment and updating user roles. Explain soft-delete implementation through the IsActive flag rather than physical deletion. Describe password management policies and how user creation handles password hashing via ASP.NET Identity. Document search and filtering capabilities with username/email queries.

wiki_catalogs.name: Backend Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the backend architecture of InventoryCtrl_2. Describe the RESTful API design using ASP.NET Core controllers, dependency injection, and middleware pipeline. Explain the separation of concerns between Controllers (HTTP interface), Services (business logic), and AppDbContext (data access). Document the use of Clean Architecture principles, repository pattern via EF Core, and CQRS-like separation in operations. Detail critical components like AuditMiddleware, AuthenticationMiddleware, and GlobalExceptionMiddleware. Include system diagrams showing request flow from HTTP entry point through validation, business logic, and database operations. Address cross-cutting concerns including JWT authentication, role-based authorization, audit logging, and error handling. Provide examples from CategoryController and ProductService implementations.

wiki_catalogs.name: User Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the User Management feature. Thoroughly explain the implementation details of authentication in AuthController, including JWT token generation and refresh token handling. Document the domain model of User with its properties like Role, RefreshToken, and RefreshTokenExpiry. Explain the service layer implementation in AuthService for login, registration, and token refresh flows. Include concrete examples from the codebase such as role-based authorization attributes and password hashing implementation. Address common issues like token expiration and solutions for secure credential storage. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers.

wiki_catalogs.name: Warehouse and Location Models
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the Warehouse and Location entities in InventoryCtrl_2. Describe Warehouse properties including Id, Name, Code, Address, and ContactInfo, and its one-to-many relationship with Location. Explain Location properties such as Id, Name, Code, Type (Storage, Picking, Receiving, etc.), Capacity, and WarehouseId. Document the hierarchical structure where multiple locations belong to a single warehouse and how this impacts inventory transactions and stock visibility. Include data validation rules and constraints (e.g., unique location codes within a warehouse). Describe how these models support inventory tracking, transaction routing, and reporting. Provide examples of common operations like warehouse creation, location assignment in transactions, and querying stock by location. Address performance considerations such as indexing on WarehouseId and Location.Type.

wiki_catalogs.name: Logout and Token Revocation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the logout process and token revocation mechanism in InventoryCtrl_2. Explain the AuthController's Logout endpoint, which requires authorization and invokes RefreshTokenService to revoke the user's refresh token by setting it to null in the database. Document how this prevents future token refresh attempts and effectively terminates the user's session. Include the role of claims-based authentication in identifying the current user during logout. Address security implications of token revocation and how it contributes to overall session management. Provide examples of successful logout responses and explain why access tokens are not explicitly invalidated (relying on short expiration).

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive API documentation for the AuthController endpoints that handle authentication and authorization. Document the POST /api/auth/login endpoint with LoginRequest schema (Username, Password), including rate limiting protection and response format with JWT token, refresh token, and user roles. Detail the POST /api/auth/refresh endpoint for token renewal using refresh tokens. Explain the POST /api/auth/logout endpoint for invalidating refresh tokens. Document the registration endpoint POST /api/auth/register with user creation flow and email uniqueness validation. Include details on JWT token structure, expiration (configurable via Jwt:ExpireMinutes), and refresh token rotation. Explain error responses for invalid credentials, locked accounts, and expired tokens. Document the [AllowAnonymous] and [Authorize] attributes used throughout the API and role-based authorization policies. Provide examples of successful authentication flow and error handling for common scenarios.

wiki_catalogs.name: Data Flow Between Layers
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on data flow in InventoryCtrl_2. Illustrate the complete pathway from user interaction in Blazor components through API clients, HTTP transport, API controllers, business services, and database persistence via Entity Framework Core. Detail both request and response flows, including how DTOs are used for data transfer between layers. Explain the role of mapping between ProductDto and Product entity, validation at multiple layers, and error propagation. Document real-time data flow through SignalR for notifications. Include sequence diagrams showing typical operations like creating a product or processing a transaction. Provide practical examples tracing specific requests through the system. Address performance considerations, serialization overhead, and optimization techniques like caching and batching.

wiki_catalogs.name: Dashboard Analytics
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Dashboard Analytics feature. Thoroughly explain the implementation details of dashboard data aggregation in DashboardController, including statistical calculations and recent activity tracking. Document the domain model of DashboardDto with its properties like TotalProducts, TotalWarehouses, and LowStockCount. Explain the service layer implementation in DashboardService for compiling system metrics. Include concrete examples from the codebase such as GetDashboardStatsAsync implementation and integration with audit logs for activity monitoring. Address common issues like data freshness and solutions for performance optimization with large datasets. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers.

wiki_catalogs.name: Category and Manufacturer Models
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the Category and Manufacturer entities in InventoryCtrl_2. For Category, detail properties such as Id, Name, Description, ParentCategoryId (for hierarchy), and audit fields. Explain its one-to-many relationship with Product and self-referencing hierarchy for subcategories. For Manufacturer, document properties including Id, Name, Description, Website, ContactEmail, and Phone. Explain its one-to-many relationship with Product. Include data validation rules like required names and uniqueness constraints. Describe how these reference data entities are used in product categorization, filtering, and reporting. Provide examples of hierarchical category queries and manufacturer-based product searches. Address performance considerations such as indexing on Name fields and caching strategies for reference data.

wiki_catalogs.name: Audit API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed API documentation for the AuditController endpoints that provide audit trail functionality. Document the GET /api/audit endpoint with comprehensive filtering options including entityName, action, actionType, entityType, userId, date ranges, and severity levels. Explain pagination implementation with page and pageSize parameters (max 100). Detail specialized endpoints like GET /api/audit/entity/{entityType}/{entityId} for entity-specific logs, GET /api/audit/user/{userId} for user activity, and GET /api/audit/trace/{requestId} for request tracing. Document the export functionality at GET /api/audit/export that returns CSV-formatted audit logs. Explain the cleanup endpoint DELETE /api/audit/cleanup (Admin only) for removing old logs based on daysToKeep parameter. Include the AuditLogDto response schema with fields like Timestamp, Action, Changes, OldValues, NewValues, and Metadata. Document authentication requirements (JWT) and authorization roles (Admin, Manager). Provide examples of querying audit logs for product updates and analyzing user activity patterns.

wiki_catalogs.name: Environment Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on environment configuration in InventoryCtrl_2. Document the use of appsettings.json files for both API and Web.Client with environment-specific overrides (Development, Staging, Production). Explain configuration sections for database connections, JWT settings, Vapid notifications, and API endpoints. Detail how configuration values are injected into services via options pattern. Cover the PowerShell deployment scripts that automate environment setup and configuration injection. Provide practical examples of configuring different environments, managing secrets, and troubleshooting configuration issues. Include guidance on adding new configuration settings and ensuring consistency across environments. Address security considerations for sensitive configuration data.

wiki_catalogs.name: Keyless Entity Views
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the keyless entity views in InventoryCtrl_2. Detail the three main views: ProductPendingView, ProductOnHandView, and ProductInstalledView. Explain their purpose in providing optimized read-only access to aggregated inventory data without requiring client-side computation. Document the SQL view definitions (from measure-before.sql and measure-after.sql) and how they are mapped using Entity Framework Core's ToView() configuration. Include property-to-column mappings via HasColumnName and the use of HasNoKey(). Describe how these views support dashboard metrics, low-stock alerts, and real-time inventory reporting. Provide examples of querying these views via DbSet and their integration with DashboardController and DashboardApiService. Address performance benefits, materialization considerations, and requirements for database-level view creation during deployment.

wiki_catalogs.name: Notification API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive API documentation for the NotificationController endpoints that manage real-time notifications. Document endpoints for retrieving notifications (GET /api/Notification), marking notifications as read (PUT /api/Notification/{id}/read), and bulk operations (POST /api/Notification/bulk/read, POST /api/Notification/bulk/delete). Detail the NotificationDto schema including properties like Title, Message, Type, IsRead, CreatedAt, and EntityLink. Explain the statistics endpoint GET /api/Notification/stats that returns unread count and notification distribution by type. Document the preferences endpoint for managing user notification settings and the rules engine configuration endpoints. Include authentication requirements (JWT) and authorization (current user can only access their own notifications). Explain the integration with SignalR for real-time push notifications via NotificationHub. Provide examples of retrieving unread notifications and updating notification preferences. Describe the cleanup endpoint for removing old notifications based on retention policies.

wiki_catalogs.name: Deployment Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the deployment architecture of InventoryCtrl_2. Describe the containerized deployment using Docker and docker-compose with separate configurations for production, staging, test, and SSL environments. Explain the nginx reverse proxy setup with SSL termination, location routing, and static file serving. Document the PowerShell deployment automation scripts for different environments (deploy-production.ps1, deploy-staging.ps1, etc.) and their diagnostic counterparts. Include network topology diagrams showing container interactions, port mappings, and external access points. Address infrastructure requirements, scalability considerations, and deployment topology options. Provide system context diagrams and component breakdowns for the deployed system. Cover SSL/TLS implementation details and troubleshooting guides from SSL_TROUBLESHOOTING.md.

wiki_catalogs.name: Reference Data API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive API documentation for all reference data endpoints that manage master data entities. Document the ManufacturerController (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE /api/Manufacturer), ProductGroupController (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE /api/ProductGroup), ProductModelController (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE /api/ProductModel), UnitOfMeasureController (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE /api/UnitOfMeasure), WarehouseController (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE /api/Warehouse), and LocationController (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE /api/Location) endpoints. Detail common patterns across these controllers including CRUD operations, pagination, and validation. Explain the hierarchical location structure with parentId relationships and root locations. Document the specialized endpoints like GET /api/UnitOfMeasure/exists for validation and GET /api/ProductGroup/all for dropdown populations. Include authentication requirements (JWT) and authorization roles (Admin, Manager). Provide examples of creating a new manufacturer and retrieving all units of measure. Explain error handling for duplicate names and referential integrity constraints.

wiki_catalogs.name: Developer Onboarding Guide
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on developer onboarding for InventoryCtrl_2. Provide step-by-step instructions for setting up a local development environment including prerequisites (.NET 8.0 SDK, PostgreSQL, Docker), cloning the repository, and running the quick-setup.ps1 script. Document the process for configuring local DNS, initializing the database with init-db.sql, and starting services via docker-compose. Include debugging tips for both backend API and Blazor frontend, with guidance on using Visual Studio/VS Code launch configurations. Provide troubleshooting solutions for common setup issues like database connectivity, SSL certificate errors, and CORS problems. Offer practical examples of making first code changes and running tests. Address platform-specific considerations for Windows development environment.

wiki_catalogs.name: Dashboard API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed API documentation for the DashboardController endpoints that provide analytics and summary data. Document the GET /api/dashboard/stats endpoint that returns key performance indicators like total products, active users, warehouses, and low-stock items. Explain the GET /api/dashboard/recent-activity endpoint that returns recent system activities with pagination. Detail the GET /api/dashboard/low-stock-products endpoint that retrieves products below their minimum stock thresholds. Include the DashboardDto response schema with properties like TotalProducts, TotalUsers, LowStockCount, and RecentActivityItems. Document authentication requirements (JWT) and authorization roles (Admin, Manager, User). Explain caching strategies for performance optimization of dashboard data. Provide examples of integrating dashboard data into UI components and handling the response data structure. Describe error responses and fallback mechanisms for unavailable dashboard statistics.

wiki_catalogs.name: Database Schema Design
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the database schema of InventoryCtrl_2. Detail all entities including Product, InventoryTransaction, User, Warehouse, Location, Category, and Manufacturer, showing their properties, data types, and relationships. Document primary/foreign keys, indexes (including performance-critical ones from AddCriticalPerformanceIndexes migration), and constraints. Explain business rules implemented through entity relationships and validation. Include an ER diagram showing table relationships and cardinality. Document data access patterns through AppDbContext and migration strategy using EF Core. Provide examples of complex queries from SQL scripts like reconcile-quantities.sql. Address performance considerations for indexing, query optimization, and data lifecycle management.

wiki_catalogs.name: Request API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive API documentation for the RequestsController endpoints that manage inventory requests. Document the GET /api/requests endpoint for retrieving paginated requests with filtering by status, and GET /api/requests/{id} for request details including transactions and history. Detail the workflow endpoints: POST /api/requests/{id}/submit, POST /api/requests/{id}/approve, POST /api/requests/{id}/received, POST /api/requests/{id}/installed, POST /api/requests/{id}/complete, POST /api/requests/{id}/cancel, and POST /api/requests/{id}/reject for managing request lifecycle. Explain the RequestDetailsDto response schema with Transactions and History collections. Document authentication requirements (JWT) and authorization rules (users can only modify their own requests, managers can approve). Include examples of submitting a new request and progressing it through the approval workflow. Describe validation rules and error responses for invalid state transitions (e.g., approving an already completed request).

wiki_catalogs.name: Security Considerations
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on security in InventoryCtrl_2. Document the JWT-based authentication flow, role-based authorization with Admin/Manager/User roles, and token management through RefreshTokenService. Explain the implementation of AuthenticationMiddleware and secure token storage practices. Cover CORS policy configuration, input validation using FluentValidation, and protection against common vulnerabilities like XSS and CSRF. Detail audit logging through AuditMiddleware and AuditService for security monitoring. Include security headers implementation in nginx and HTTPS enforcement. Provide guidance on secure deployment practices, secret management, and regular security audits. Address compliance considerations and data protection requirements.

wiki_catalogs.name: Testing Strategy
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the testing strategy of InventoryCtrl_2. Document the three-tier testing approach with unit tests (business logic), integration tests (API endpoints), and component tests (Blazor UI). Explain the structure of test projects, use of xUnit, and testing patterns like Arrange-Act-Assert. Detail test coverage for critical functionality including authentication, transaction processing, and error handling. Include guidance on writing new tests, using test fixtures, and test data management through TestUsers and TestProducts. Provide examples of mocking services and testing edge cases. Cover test execution via run-tests.ps1 and CI/CD integration. Address performance testing considerations and code coverage analysis.

wiki_catalogs.name: Feature-Specific Technical Design
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on feature-specific technical designs in InventoryCtrl_2. Provide in-depth analysis of key features including Product Management, Inventory Transactions, Real-time Notifications, Audit Logging, User Management, and Dashboard Analytics. For each feature, document the domain model, service layer implementation, API endpoints, and UI integration points. Explain business rules, validation requirements, and edge cases. Include sequence diagrams showing operation flows and state transitions. Provide practical examples from the codebase like transaction type handling in TransactionController or notification rules in NotificationRuleEngine. Address performance considerations, error handling strategies, and extensibility points for each feature.

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# Comprehensive Project Analysis: Inventory Control System v2

## 1. Project Introduction

The Inventory Control System v2 is a modern inventory management solution built on ASP.NET Core 8.0 and Blazor WebAssembly with real-time capabilities through SignalR. This system provides comprehensive inventory management functionality for organizations needing to track products, categories, manufacturers, warehouses, and transactions across multiple locations.

**Core Goals and Objectives:**
- Provide a complete inventory management solution with CRUD operations for all inventory entities
- Implement real-time notifications using SignalR for immediate updates
- Ensure secure access through JWT authentication with role-based authorization (Admin, Manager, User)
- Maintain full audit trails of all user actions and system changes
- Deliver an intuitive user interface with responsive design and dashboard analytics

**Target Audience:**
- Enterprise inventory managers and warehouse supervisors
- System administrators responsible for maintaining inventory data
- Developers extending the system with new features or integrations
- Operations teams requiring real-time visibility into inventory levels

Sources:
- [README.md](README.md)

## 2. Technical Architecture

### Component Breakdown

The project follows a Clean Architecture pattern with clear separation of concerns across multiple components:

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[Blazor Web Client] --> B[API Gateway]
    B --> C[Inventory.API]
    C --> D[Business Logic]
    D --> E[Data Access]
    E --> F[(PostgreSQL Database)]
    G[Shared Components] --> C
    G --> A
    H[SignalR Hub] --> A
    H --> C
```

The architecture consists of several key components:
- **Inventory.Web.Client**: Blazor WebAssembly frontend application providing the user interface
- **Inventory.API**: ASP.NET Core Web API backend handling business logic and data persistence
- **Inventory.Shared**: Shared library containing DTOs, interfaces, and services used by both client and server
- **Inventory.UI**: Reusable UI components library
- **Inventory.Web.Assets**: Razor Class Library for shared static resources (CSS/JS)

### Design Patterns

The system implements several architectural patterns:
- **Clean Architecture**: Clear separation between presentation, application, domain, and infrastructure layers
- **Repository Pattern**: Data access abstraction through Entity Framework Core
- **Dependency Injection**: Comprehensive DI container usage throughout the application
- **CQRS Lite**: Separation of read and write operations in API controllers
- **Mediator Pattern**: Implicitly used through the service layer abstraction

### System Relationships

```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Inventory.Web.Client] -->|HTTP/SignalR| B[Inventory.API]
    B -->|Entity Framework| C[PostgreSQL]
    B -->|SignalR| A
    D[Inventory.Shared] --> A
    D --> B
    E[Inventory.UI] --> A
    F[Inventory.Web.Assets] --> A
```

The client-server relationship is established through RESTful API calls and SignalR connections for real-time communication. The shared library enables type safety and consistency between client and server while reducing code duplication.

### Data Flow

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[User Interaction] --> B[Blazor Component]
    B --> C[WebProductApiService]
    C --> D[HttpClient]
    D --> E[API Endpoint]
    E --> F[ProductController]
    F --> G[Business Validation]
    G --> H[AuditService]
    H --> I[AppDbContext]
    I --> J[(Database)]
    J --> K[Return Data]
    K --> L[SignalR Notification]
    L --> M[All Connected Clients]
```

Data flows from the user interface through the service layer to the API, where it undergoes validation, business logic processing, auditing, and persistence. Changes are then broadcast to relevant clients via SignalR for real-time updates.

Sources:
- [Program.cs](src/Inventory.API/Program.cs)
- [Program.cs](src/Inventory.Web.Client/Program.cs)
- [AppDbContext.cs](src/Inventory.API/Models/AppDbContext.cs)

## 3. Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
- Backend: `src/Inventory.API/Program.cs` - API startup and configuration
- Frontend: `src/Inventory.Web.Client/Program.cs` - Blazor WebAssembly initialization

### Core Modules
- **Product Management**: Comprehensive product catalog with categories, manufacturers, and models
- **Authentication & Authorization**: JWT-based security with role-based access control
- **Real-time Notifications**: SignalR-powered notification system for instant updates
- **Audit Logging**: Complete tracking of all entity changes with user context
- **Rate Limiting**: Protection against abuse with configurable limits per user role

### Configuration Approach
The system uses a multi-layered configuration approach with environment-specific settings:

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Environment Variables] --> B[appsettings.json]
    C[User Secrets] --> B
    D[Docker Environment] --> B
    B --> E[Configuration Service]
    E --> F[Application Services]
```

Configuration is managed through ASP.NET Core's IConfiguration system, supporting multiple sources including environment variables, JSON files, and user secrets for development.

### External Dependencies
- .NET 8.0 SDK and runtime
- PostgreSQL 14+ database server
- Docker for containerized deployment
- Nginx as reverse proxy in production

### Integration Points
- **SignalR**: Real-time communication between server and clients
- **JWT Authentication**: Secure token-based authentication
- **Entity Framework Core**: Database persistence with PostgreSQL
- **Serilog**: Structured logging with multiple sinks
- **FluentValidation**: Model validation across client and server

### Component Relationships

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Inventory.Web.Client] --> B[WebProductApiService]
    A --> C[WebAuthApiService]
    A --> D[SignalRService]
    B --> E[ProductApiService]
    C --> F[AuthApiService]
    E --> G[BaseApiService]
    F --> G
    H[Inventory.API] --> I[ProductController]
    H --> J[AuthController]
    H --> K[NotificationHub]
    I --> L[ProductService]
    J --> M[AuthService]
    L --> N[AuditService]
    L --> O[AppDbContext]
    M --> P[RefreshTokenService]
    K --> Q[SignalRNotificationService]
```

The component relationships demonstrate a well-structured dependency graph with clear boundaries between concerns. The shared services provide common functionality while specialized services handle domain-specific logic.

Sources:
- [Program.cs](src/Inventory.API/Program.cs)
- [Program.cs](src/Inventory.Web.Client/Program.cs)
- [ProductController.cs](src/Inventory.API/Controllers/ProductController.cs)
- [ProductApiService.cs](src/Inventory.Shared/Services/ProductApiService.cs)
- [WebProductApiService.cs](src/Inventory.Web.Client/Services/WebProductApiService.cs)
- [NotificationHub.cs](src/Inventory.API/Hubs/NotificationHub.cs)

## 4. Key Features

### Functionality Overview
The Inventory Control System offers comprehensive inventory management capabilities:
- Product catalog management with hierarchical categories
- Multi-warehouse inventory tracking with location-level precision
- Real-time stock level monitoring with low-stock alerts
- Complete audit trail of all system changes
- Role-based access control with Admin, Manager, and User roles
- Responsive dashboard with key performance metrics
- RESTful API with Swagger documentation
- Real-time notifications via SignalR

### Implementation Highlights
- **Real-time Updates**: Implemented using SignalR hubs for instant notification delivery
- **Soft Deletes**: Products are deactivated rather than permanently removed
- **Audit Trail**: Every entity change is logged with before/after values
- **Rate Limiting**: Configurable limits based on user roles to prevent abuse
- **Input Validation**: Comprehensive validation using FluentValidation
- **Error Handling**: Centralized exception handling with meaningful error responses

### Feature Architecture

```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> Idle
    Idle --> ProductManagement: User navigates to Products
    ProductManagement --> CreateProduct: Click "Add Product"
    CreateProduct --> ValidateInput: Submit form
    ValidateInput --> SaveProduct: Valid data
    ValidateInput --> ShowErrors: Invalid data
    SaveProduct --> AuditLog: Persist to database
    AuditLog --> NotifyClients: SignalR broadcast
    NotifyClients --> UpdateUI: Real-time update
    UpdateUI --> ProductManagement: Display success
    ProductManagement --> AdjustStock: Initiate stock adjustment
    AdjustStock --> CreateTransaction: Record inventory movement
    CreateTransaction --> AuditLog: Log change
    AuditLog --> NotifyClients: Broadcast update
    NotifyClients --> UpdateDashboard: Refresh statistics
    UpdateDashboard --> ProductManagement: Complete
```

The feature architecture demonstrates a cohesive workflow from user interaction through business logic to data persistence and real-time notification. Each action triggers appropriate auditing and notification mechanisms to maintain system integrity and keep users informed.

Sources:
- [ProductController.cs](src/Inventory.API/Controllers/ProductController.cs)
- [ProductDto.cs](src/Inventory.Shared/DTOs/ProductDto.cs)
- [Product.cs](src/Inventory.Shared/Models/Product.cs)
- [NotificationHub.cs](src/Inventory.API/Hubs/NotificationHub.cs)
</blog>
